Value Iteration and Policy Iteration

Posted on 2025-03-05 Edited on 2025-03-24 In Computer Science Views:
Symbols count in article: 3.2k Reading time ≈ 16 mins.
Value Iteration and Policy Iteration, Truncated Policy Iteration.

Sources:

  1. Shiyu Zhao. Chapter 4: OValue Iteration and Policy Iteration
  2. Youtube: Value Iteration
  3. Youtube: Policy Iteration
  4. Youtube: Truncated Policy Iteration

This postintroduces three algorithms that are closely related to each other, which are the solution of BOE to get optimal policies.

The algorithms introduced in this chapter are called dynamic programming algorithms

Recall that the Bellman optimality equation：

v=f(v)=max⁡π(rπ+γPπv)v = f(v) = \max_{\pi}(r_{\pi} + \gamma P_{\pi}v) v=f(v)=πmax​(rπ​+γPπ​v)

Value iteration algorithm

The contraction mapping theorem suggests an iterative algorithm:

vk+1=f(vk)=max⁡π(rπ+γPπvk),k=1,2,3,…v_{k+1} = f(v_k) = \max_{\pi}(r_\pi + \gamma P_\pi v_k), \quad k = 1, 2, 3, \ldots vk+1​=f(vk​)=πmax​(rπ​+γPπ​vk​),k=1,2,3,…

where v0v_0v0​ can be arbitrary. This algorithm can eventually find the optimal state value and an optimal policy.

This algorithm is called value iteration. It can be decomposed to two steps.

The value iteration algorithm can be decomposed into two steps:

  • Step 1: Policy Update

    This step is to solve

    πk+1=arg⁡max⁡π(rπ+γPπvk)\pi_{k+1} = \arg \max_{\pi}(r_{\pi} + \gamma P_{\pi} v_k) πk+1​=argπmax​(rπ​+γPπ​vk​)

    where vkv_kvk​ is given.

  • Step 2: Value Update

    vk+1=rπk+1+γPπk+1vkv_{k+1} = r_{\pi_{k+1}} + \gamma P_{\pi_{k+1}} v_k vk+1​=rπk+1​​+γPπk+1​​vk​

Question: Is vkv_kvk​ a state value?

Answer: No, because it is not ensured that vkv_kvk​ satisfies a Bellman equation.

To implement this algorithm, we need to further examine its elementwise form.

Step1: Policy update

The elementwise form of

πk+1=arg⁡max⁡π(rπ+γPπvk)\pi_{k+1} = \arg \max_{\pi}(r_\pi + \gamma P_\pi v_k) πk+1​=argπmax​(rπ​+γPπ​vk​)

is

πk+1(s)=arg⁡max⁡π∑aπ(a∣s)(∑rp(r∣s,a)r+γ∑s′p(s′∣s,a)vk(s′)⏟qk(s,a)),s∈S\pi_{k+1}(s) = \arg \max_{\pi} \sum_a \pi(a|s) \left( \underbrace{\sum_r p(r|s,a) r + \gamma \sum_{s'} p(s'|s,a) v_k(s')}_{q_k(s,a)} \right), \quad s \in S πk+1​(s)=argπmax​a∑​π(a∣s)⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​qk​(s,a)r∑​p(r∣s,a)r+γs′∑​p(s′∣s,a)vk​(s′)​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​,s∈S

The optimal policy solving the above optimization problem is

πk+1(a∣s)={1a=ak∗(s)0a≠ak∗(s)\pi_{k+1}(a|s) = \begin{cases} 1 & a = a^*_k(s) \\ 0 & a \neq a^*_k(s) \end{cases} πk+1​(a∣s)={10​a=ak∗​(s)a=ak∗​(s)​

where ak∗(s)=arg⁡max⁡aqk(a,s)a^*_k(s) = \arg \max_a q_k(a,s)ak∗​(s)=argmaxa​qk​(a,s). πk+1\pi_{k+1}πk+1​ is called a greedy policy, since it simply selects the greatest q-value.

Step2: Value update

The elementwise form of

vk+1=rπk+1+γPπk+1vkv_{k+1} = r_{\pi_{k+1}} + \gamma P_{\pi_{k+1}} v_k vk+1​=rπk+1​​+γPπk+1​​vk​

is

vk+1(s)=∑aπk+1(a∣s)(∑rp(r∣s,a)r+γ∑s′p(s′∣s,a)vk(s′)),s∈Sv_{k+1}(s) = \sum_a \pi_{k+1}(a|s) \left( \sum_r p(r|s, a)r + \gamma \sum_{s'} p(s'|s, a)v_k(s') \right), \quad s \in \mathcal{S} vk+1​(s)=a∑​πk+1​(a∣s)(r∑​p(r∣s,a)r+γs′∑​p(s′∣s,a)vk​(s′)),s∈S

Since πk+1\pi_{k+1}πk+1​ is greedy, the above equation is simply

vk+1(s)=max⁡aqk(a,s)v_{k+1}(s) = \max_a q_k(a, s) vk+1​(s)=amax​qk​(a,s)

Pseudocode

Procedure summary:

vk(s)→qk(s,a)→greedy policy πk+1(a∣s)→new value vk+1=max⁡aqk(s,a)v_{k}(s) \rightarrow q_{k}(s,a) \rightarrow \text{greedy policy } \pi_{k+1}(a|s) \rightarrow \text{new value } v_{k+1} = \max_{a} q_{k}(s,a) vk​(s)→qk​(s,a)→greedy policy πk+1​(a∣s)→new value vk+1​=amax​qk​(s,a)

  • k=2,3,…k = 2, 3, \ldotsk=2,3,… Stop when ∥vk−vk+1∥\|v_k - v_{k+1}\|∥vk​−vk+1​∥ is smaller than a predefined threshold.

Policy iteration algorithm

Given a random initial policy π0\pi_0π0​,

  • Step 1: Policy Evaluation (PE)

    This step is to calculate the state value of πk\pi_kπk​:

    vπk=rπk+γPπkvπkv_{\pi_k} = r_{\pi_k} + \gamma P_{\pi_k} v_{\pi_k} vπk​​=rπk​​+γPπk​​vπk​​

    Note that vπkv_{\pi_k}vπk​​ is a state value function.

  • Step 2: Policy Improvement (PI)

    πk+1=arg⁡max⁡π(rπ+γPπvπk)\pi_{k+1} = \arg \max_{\pi}(r_{\pi} + \gamma P_{\pi} v_{\pi_k}) πk+1​=argπmax​(rπ​+γPπ​vπk​​)

    The maximization is componentwise!

Some questions

how to get the state value vπkv_{\pi_k}vπk​​

In the policy evaluation step, how to get the state value vπkv_{\pi_k}vπk​​ by solving the Bellman equation?

vπk=rπk+γPπkvπkv_{\pi_k} = r_{\pi_k} + \gamma P_{\pi_k} v_{\pi_k} vπk​​=rπk​​+γPπk​​vπk​​

it can be recalled in the post

  • Closed-form solution:

    vπk=(I−γPπk)−1rπkv_{\pi_k} = (I - \gamma P_{\pi_k})^{-1} r_{\pi_k} vπk​​=(I−γPπk​​)−1rπk​​

  • Iterative solution:

    vπk(j+1)=rπk+γPπkvπk(j),j=0,1,2,…v^{(j+1)}_{\pi_k} = r_{\pi_k} + \gamma P_{\pi_k} v^{(j)}_{\pi_k}, \quad j = 0, 1, 2, \ldots vπk​(j+1)​=rπk​​+γPπk​​vπk​(j)​,j=0,1,2,…

Already studied in the lecture about Bellman equation.

  • Policy iteration is an iterative algorithm with another iterative algorithm embedded in the policy evaluation step!

why is the new policy πk+1\pi_{k+1}πk+1​ better than πk\pi_kπk​

In the policy improvement step, why is the new policy πk+1\pi_{k+1}πk+1​ better than πk\pi_kπk​?

Lemma 4.1 (Policy Improvement)

If πk+1=arg⁡max⁡π(rπ+γPπvπk)\pi_{k+1} = \arg\max_{\pi}(r_{\pi} + \gamma P_{\pi}v_{\pi_k})πk+1​=argmaxπ​(rπ​+γPπ​vπk​​), then vπk+1≥vπkv_{\pi_{k+1}} \geq v_{\pi_k}vπk+1​​≥vπk​​ for any kkk.

The proof of this lemma is as follows:

Since vπk+1v_{\pi_{k+1}}vπk+1​​ and vπkv_{\pi_k}vπk​​ are state values, they satisfy the Bellman equations:

vπk+1=rπk+1+γPπk+1vπk+1,vπk=rπk+γPπkvπk.\begin{aligned} v_{\pi_{k+1}} &= r_{\pi_{k+1}} + \gamma P_{\pi_{k+1}} v_{\pi_{k+1}}, \\ v_{\pi_k} &= r_{\pi_k} + \gamma P_{\pi_k} v_{\pi_k}. \end{aligned} vπk+1​​vπk​​​=rπk+1​​+γPπk+1​​vπk+1​​,=rπk​​+γPπk​​vπk​​.​

Since πk+1=arg⁡max⁡π(rπ+γPπvπk)\pi_{k+1} = \arg \max_\pi (r_\pi + \gamma P_\pi v_{\pi_k})πk+1​=argmaxπ​(rπ​+γPπ​vπk​​), we know that

rπk+1+γPπk+1vπk≥rπk+γPπkvπk.r_{\pi_{k+1}} + \gamma P_{\pi_{k+1}} v_{\pi_k} \geq r_{\pi_k} + \gamma P_{\pi_k} v_{\pi_k}. rπk+1​​+γPπk+1​​vπk​​≥rπk​​+γPπk​​vπk​​.

It then follows that

vπk−vπk+1=(rπk+γPπkvπk)−(rπk+1+γPπk+1vπk+1)≤(rπk+1+γPπk+1vπk)−(rπk+1+γPπk+1vπk+1)≤γPπk+1(vπk−vπk+1).\begin{aligned} v_{\pi_{k}} - v_{\pi_{k+1}} &= (r_{\pi_{k}} + \gamma P_{\pi_{k}}v_{\pi_{k}}) - (r_{\pi_{k+1}} + \gamma P_{\pi_{k+1}}v_{\pi_{k+1}}) \\ &\leq (r_{\pi_{k+1}} + \gamma P_{\pi_{k+1}}v_{\pi_{k}}) - (r_{\pi_{k+1}} + \gamma P_{\pi_{k+1}}v_{\pi_{k+1}}) \\ &\leq \gamma P_{\pi_{k+1}}(v_{\pi_{k}} - v_{\pi_{k+1}}). \end{aligned} vπk​​−vπk+1​​​=(rπk​​+γPπk​​vπk​​)−(rπk+1​​+γPπk+1​​vπk+1​​)≤(rπk+1​​+γPπk+1​​vπk​​)−(rπk+1​​+γPπk+1​​vπk+1​​)≤γPπk+1​​(vπk​​−vπk+1​​).​

Therefore,

vπk−vπk+1≤γ2Pπk+12(vπk−vπk+1)≤⋯≤γnPπk+1n(vπk−vπk+1)≤lim⁡n→∞γnPπk+1n(vπk−vπk+1)=0.\begin{aligned} v_{\pi_{k}} - v_{\pi_{k+1}} &\leq \gamma^{2}P_{\pi_{k+1}}^{2}(v_{\pi_{k}} - v_{\pi_{k+1}}) \leq \cdots \leq \gamma^{n}P_{\pi_{k+1}}^{n}(v_{\pi_{k}} - v_{\pi_{k+1}}) \\ &\leq \lim_{n \to \infty} \gamma^{n}P_{\pi_{k+1}}^{n}(v_{\pi_{k}} - v_{\pi_{k+1}}) = 0. \end{aligned} vπk​​−vπk+1​​​≤γ2Pπk+1​2​(vπk​​−vπk+1​​)≤⋯≤γnPπk+1​n​(vπk​​−vπk+1​​)≤n→∞lim​γnPπk+1​n​(vπk​​−vπk+1​​)=0.​

The limit is due to the facts that γn→0\gamma^{n} \to 0γn→0 as n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞ and Pπk+1nP_{\pi_{k+1}}^{n}Pπk+1​n​ is a nonnegative stochastic matrix for any nnn. Here, a stochastic matrix refers to a nonnegative matrix whose row sums are equal to one for all rows.

Why can finally reach an optimal policy?

Since every iteration would improve the policy, we know

vπ0≤vπ1≤vπ2≤⋯≤vπk≤⋯≤v∗v_{\pi_0} \leq v_{\pi_1} \leq v_{\pi_2} \leq \cdots \leq v_{\pi_k} \leq \cdots \leq v^* vπ0​​≤vπ1​​≤vπ2​​≤⋯≤vπk​​≤⋯≤v∗

As a result, vπkv_{\pi_k}vπk​​ keeps increasing and will converge.

Still need to prove what value it converges to.

Theorem (Convergence of Policy Iteration)

The state value sequence {vπk}k=0∞\{v_{\pi_k}\}_{k=0}^{\infty}{vπk​​}k=0∞​ generated by the policy iteration algorithm converges to the optimal state value v∗v^*v∗. As a result, the policy sequence {πk}k=0∞\{\pi_k\}_{k=0}^{\infty}{πk​}k=0∞​ converges to an optimal policy.

the proof of this theorem is as follows:

The idea of the proof is to show that the policy iteration algorithm converges faster than the value iteration algorithm.

In particular, to prove the convergence of {vπk}k=0∞\{v_{\pi_{k}}\}_{k=0}^{\infty}{vπk​​}k=0∞​, we introduce another sequence {vk}k=0∞\{v_{k}\}_{k=0}^{\infty}{vk​}k=0∞​ generated by

vk+1=f(vk)=max⁡π(rπ+γPπvk).v_{k+1}=f(v_{k})=\max_{\pi}(r_{\pi}+\gamma P_{\pi}v_{k}). vk+1​=f(vk​)=πmax​(rπ​+γPπ​vk​).

This iterative algorithm is exactly the value iteration algorithm. We already know that vkv_{k}vk​ converges to v∗v^{*}v∗ when given any initial value v0v_{0}v0​.

For k=0k=0k=0, we can always find a v0v_{0}v0​ such that vπ0≥v0v_{\pi_{0}}\geq v_{0}vπ0​​≥v0​ for any π0\pi_{0}π0​.

We next show that vk≤vπk≤v∗v_{k}\leq v_{\pi_{k}}\leq v^{*}vk​≤vπk​​≤v∗ for all kkk by induction.

For k≥0k\geq 0k≥0, suppose that vπk≥vkv_{\pi_{k}}\geq v_{k}vπk​​≥vk​.

For k+1k+1k+1, we have

vπk+1−vk+1=(rπk+1+γPπk+1vπk+1)−max⁡π(rπ+γPπvk)≥(rπk+1+γPπk+1vπk)−max⁡π(rπ+γPπvk) (because vπk+1≥vπk by Lemma 4.1 and Pπk+1≥0 ) =(rπk+1+γPπk+1vπk)−(rπk′+γPπk′vk) (suppose πk′=arg⁡max⁡π(rπ+γPπvk))≥(rπk′+γPπk′vπk)−(rπk′+γPπk′vk) (because πk+1=arg⁡max⁡π(rπ+γPπvπk) ) =γPπk′(vπk−vk).\begin{aligned} v_{\pi_{k+1}}-v_{k+1} &=\left(r_{\pi_{k+1}}+\gamma P_{\pi_{k+1}} v_{\pi_{k+1}}\right)-\max _{\pi}\left(r_{\pi}+\gamma P_{\pi} v_{k}\right) \\ &\geq\left(r_{\pi_{k+1}}+\gamma P_{\pi_{k+1}} v_{\pi_{k}}\right)-\max _{\pi}\left(r_{\pi}+\gamma P_{\pi} v_{k}\right) \\ &\quad \quad \quad \text { (because } v_{\pi_{k+1}} \geq v_{\pi_{k}} \text { by Lemma } 4.1 \text { and } P_{\pi_{k+1}} \geq 0 \text { ) } \\ &=\left(r_{\pi_{k+1}}+\gamma P_{\pi_{k+1}} v_{\pi_{k}}\right)-\left(r_{\pi_{k}^{\prime}}+\gamma P_{\pi_{k}^{\prime}} v_{k}\right) \\ &\quad \quad \quad \text { (suppose } \left.\pi_{k}^{\prime}=\arg \max _{\pi}\left(r_{\pi}+\gamma P_{\pi} v_{k}\right)\right) \\ &\geq\left(r_{\pi_{k}^{\prime}}+\gamma P_{\pi_{k}^{\prime}} v_{\pi_{k}}\right)-\left(r_{\pi_{k}^{\prime}}+\gamma P_{\pi_{k}^{\prime}} v_{k}\right) \\ &\quad \quad \quad \text { (because } \pi_{k+1}=\arg \max _{\pi}\left(r_{\pi}+\gamma P_{\pi} v_{\pi_{k}}\right) \text { ) } \\ &=\gamma P_{\pi_{k}^{\prime}}\left(v_{\pi_{k}}-v_{k}\right) . \end{aligned} vπk+1​​−vk+1​​=(rπk+1​​+γPπk+1​​vπk+1​​)−πmax​(rπ​+γPπ​vk​)≥(rπk+1​​+γPπk+1​​vπk​​)−πmax​(rπ​+γPπ​vk​) (because vπk+1​​≥vπk​​ by Lemma 4.1 and Pπk+1​​≥0 ) =(rπk+1​​+γPπk+1​​vπk​​)−(rπk′​​+γPπk′​​vk​) (suppose πk′​=argπmax​(rπ​+γPπ​vk​))≥(rπk′​​+γPπk′​​vπk​​)−(rπk′​​+γPπk′​​vk​) (because πk+1​=argπmax​(rπ​+γPπ​vπk​​) ) =γPπk′​​(vπk​​−vk​).​

Since vπk−vk≥0v_{\pi_{k}}-v_{k}\geq 0vπk​​−vk​≥0 and Pπk′P_{\pi^{\prime}_{k}}Pπk′​​ is nonnegative, we have Pπk′(vπk−vk)≥0P_{\pi^{\prime}_{k}}(v_{\pi_{k}}-v_{k})\geq 0Pπk′​​(vπk​​−vk​)≥0 and hence vπk+1−vk+1≥0v_{\pi_{k+1}}-v_{k+1}\geq 0vπk+1​​−vk+1​≥0.

Therefore, we can show by induction that vk≤vπk≤v∗v_{k}\leq v_{\pi_{k}}\leq v^{*}vk​≤vπk​​≤v∗ for any k≥0k\geq 0k≥0. Since vkv_{k}vk​ converges to v∗v^{*}v∗, vπkv_{\pi_{k}}vπk​​ also converges to v∗v^{*}v∗.

Step1: Policy evaluation

  • Matrix-vector form:

    vπk(j+1)=rπk+γPπkvπk(j),j=0,1,2,…v_{\pi_k}^{(j+1)} = r_{\pi_k} + \gamma P_{\pi_k} v_{\pi_k}^{(j)}, \quad j = 0, 1, 2, \ldots vπk​(j+1)​=rπk​​+γPπk​​vπk​(j)​,j=0,1,2,…

  • Elementwise form:

    vπk(j+1)(s)=∑aπk(a∣s)(∑rp(r∣s,a)r+γ∑s′p(s′∣s,a)vπk(j)(s′)),s∈Sv_{\pi_k}^{(j+1)}(s) = \sum_a \pi_k (a|s) \left( \sum_r p(r|s,a)r + \gamma \sum_{s'} p(s'|s,a)v_{\pi_k}^{(j)}(s') \right), \quad s \in \mathcal{S} vπk​(j+1)​(s)=a∑​πk​(a∣s)(r∑​p(r∣s,a)r+γs′∑​p(s′∣s,a)vπk​(j)​(s′)),s∈S

Stop when jjj is sufficiently large or ∥vπk(j+1)−vπk(j)∥\|v_{\pi_k}^{(j+1)} - v_{\pi_k}^{(j)}\|∥vπk​(j+1)​−vπk​(j)​∥ is sufficiently small.

Step 2: Policy improvement

Matrix-vector form: πk+1=arg⁡max⁡π(rπ+γPπvπk)\pi_{k+1} = \arg\max_{\pi}(r_\pi + \gamma P_\pi v_{\pi_k})πk+1​=argmaxπ​(rπ​+γPπ​vπk​​)

Elementwise form

πk+1(s)=arg⁡max⁡π∑aπ(a∣s)(∑rp(r∣s,a)r+γ∑s′p(s′∣s,a)vπk(s′)),s∈S.\pi_{k+1}(s) = \arg\max_{\pi} \sum_a \pi(a|s) \left( \sum_r p(r|s,a) r + \gamma \sum_s' p(s'|s,a) v_{\pi_k}(s') \right), \quad s \in S. πk+1​(s)=argπmax​a∑​π(a∣s)(r∑​p(r∣s,a)r+γs∑′​p(s′∣s,a)vπk​​(s′)),s∈S.

Here, qπk(s,a)q_{\pi_k}(s,a)qπk​​(s,a) is the action value under policy πk\pi_kπk​. Let

ak∗(s)=arg⁡max⁡aqπk(a,s)a_k^*(s) = \arg\max_a q_{\pi_k}(a,s) ak∗​(s)=argamax​qπk​​(a,s)

Then, the greedy policy is

πk+1(a∣s)={1a=ak∗(s),0a≠ak∗(s).\pi_{k+1}(a|s) = \begin{cases} 1 & a = a_k^*(s), \\ 0 & a \neq a_k^*(s). \end{cases} πk+1​(a∣s)={10​a=ak∗​(s),a=ak∗​(s).​

Pseudocode

Procedure summary:

π0→PEvπ0→PIπ1→PEvπ1→PIπ2→PEvπ2→PI…\pi_0 \xrightarrow{PE} v_{\pi_0} \xrightarrow{PI} \pi_1 \xrightarrow{PE} v_{\pi_1} \xrightarrow{PI} \pi_2 \xrightarrow{PE} v_{\pi_2} \xrightarrow{PI} \ldots π0​PE​vπ0​​PI​π1​PE​vπ1​​PI​π2​PE​vπ2​​PI​…

Example

The reward setting is rboundary=−1r_{\text{boundary}} = -1rboundary​=−1 and rtarget=1r_{\text{target}} = 1rtarget​=1. The discount rate is

γ=0.9.\gamma = 0.9. γ=0.9.

Actions: aℓa_\ellaℓ​, a0a_0a0​, ara_rar​ represent go left, stay unchanged, and go right.

Aim: use policy iteration to find out the optimal policy.

Step 1: policy evaluation

Iteration k=0k = 0k=0:

Step 1: policy evaluation

π0\pi_0π0​ is selected as the policy in Figure (a). The Bellman equation is

vπ0(s1)=−1+γvπ0(s1),v_{\pi_0}(s_1) = -1 + \gamma v_{\pi_0}(s_1), vπ0​​(s1​)=−1+γvπ0​​(s1​),

vπ0(s2)=0+γvπ0(s1).v_{\pi_0}(s_2) = 0 + \gamma v_{\pi_0}(s_1). vπ0​​(s2​)=0+γvπ0​​(s1​).

  • Solve the equations directly:

vπ0(s1)=−10,vπ0(s2)=−9.v_{\pi_0}(s_1) = -10, \quad v_{\pi_0}(s_2) = -9. vπ0​​(s1​)=−10,vπ0​​(s2​)=−9.

  • Solve the equations iteratively. Select the initial guess as

    vr0(0)(s1)=vr0(0)(s2)=0v_{r_0}^{(0)}(s_1) = v_{r_0}^{(0)}(s_2) = 0 vr0​(0)​(s1​)=vr0​(0)​(s2​)=0

{vπ0(1)(s1)=−1+γvπ0(0)(s1)=−1,vπ0(1)(s2)=0+γvπ0(0)(s1)=0,{vπ0(2)(s1)=−1+γvπ0(1)(s1)=−1.9,vπ0(2)(s2)=0+γvπ0(1)(s1)=−0.9,{vπ0(3)(s1)=−1+γvπ0(2)(s1)=−2.71,vπ0(3)(s2)=0+γvπ0(2)(s1)=−1.71,⋯\begin{aligned} &\left\{\begin{array} {c}v_{\pi_0}^{(1)}(s_1)=-1+\gamma v_{\pi_0}^{(0)}(s_1)=-1,\\ v_{\pi_0}^{(1)}(s_2)=0+\gamma v_{\pi_0}^{(0)}(s_1)=0,\end{array} \right.\\&\left\{\begin{array} {c}v_{\pi_0}^{(2)}(s_1)=-1+\gamma v_{\pi_0}^{(1)}(s_1)=-1.9,\\ v_{\pi_0}^{(2)}(s_2)=0+\gamma v_{\pi_0}^{(1)}(s_1)=-0.9,\end{array} \right.&\\&\left\{\begin{array} {c}v_{\pi_0}^{(3)}(s_1)=-1+\gamma v_{\pi_0}^{(2)}(s_1)=-2.71,\\ v_{\pi_0}^{(3)}(s_2)=0+\gamma v_{\pi_0}^{(2)}(s_1)=-1.71,\end{array}\right. \\ &\cdots \end{aligned} ​{vπ0​(1)​(s1​)=−1+γvπ0​(0)​(s1​)=−1,vπ0​(1)​(s2​)=0+γvπ0​(0)​(s1​)=0,​{vπ0​(2)​(s1​)=−1+γvπ0​(1)​(s1​)=−1.9,vπ0​(2)​(s2​)=0+γvπ0​(1)​(s1​)=−0.9,​{vπ0​(3)​(s1​)=−1+γvπ0​(2)​(s1​)=−2.71,vπ0​(3)​(s2​)=0+γvπ0​(2)​(s1​)=−1.71,​⋯​​

Step 2: policy improvement

Iteration k=0k = 0k=0:

Step 2: policy improvement

The expression of qπk(s,a)q_{\pi_k}(s, a)qπk​​(s,a):

qπk(s,a)q_{\pi_k}(s, a)qπk​​(s,a) aℓa_\ellaℓ​ a0a_0a0​ ara_rar​
s1s_1s1​ −1+γvπk(s1)-1 + \gamma v_{\pi_k}(s_1)−1+γvπk​​(s1​) 0+γvπk(s1)0 + \gamma v_{\pi_k}(s_1)0+γvπk​​(s1​) 1+γvπk(s2)1 + \gamma v_{\pi_k}(s_2)1+γvπk​​(s2​)
s2s_2s2​ 0+γvπk(s1)0 + \gamma v_{\pi_k}(s_1)0+γvπk​​(s1​) 1+γvπk(s2)1 + \gamma v_{\pi_k}(s_2)1+γvπk​​(s2​) −1+γvπk(s2)-1 + \gamma v_{\pi_k}(s_2)−1+γvπk​​(s2​)

Substituting vπ0(s1)=−10v_{\pi_0}(s_1) = -10vπ0​​(s1​)=−10, vπ0(s2)=−9v_{\pi_0}(s_2) = -9vπ0​​(s2​)=−9 and γ=0.9\gamma = 0.9γ=0.9 gives

By seeking the greatest value of qπ0q_{\pi_0}qπ0​​, the improved policy is:

π1(ar∣s1)=1,π1(a0∣s2)=1.\pi_1(a_r | s_1) = 1, \quad \pi_1(a_0 | s_2) = 1. π1​(ar​∣s1​)=1,π1​(a0​∣s2​)=1.

This policy is optimal after one iteration! In your programming, should continue until the stopping criterion is satisfied.

Truncated policy iteration algorithm

Truncated policy iteration is a more general algorithm, an the value iteration and policy iteration algorithms are two special cases of the truncated policy iteration algorithm.

Comparing value iteration and policy iteration

Policy iteration: start from π0\pi_0π0​

● Policy evaluation (PE):

vπk=rπk+γPπkvπkv_{\pi_k} = r_{\pi_k} + \gamma P_{\pi_k} v_{\pi_k} vπk​​=rπk​​+γPπk​​vπk​​

● Policy improvement (PI):

πk+1=arg⁡max⁡π(rπ+γPπvπk)\pi_{k+1} = \arg \max_{\pi} (r_{\pi} + \gamma P_{\pi} v_{\pi_k}) πk+1​=argπmax​(rπ​+γPπ​vπk​​)

Value iteration: start from v0v_0v0​

● Policy update (PU):

πk+1=arg⁡max⁡π(rπ+γPπvk)\pi_{k+1} = \arg \max_{\pi} (r_{\pi} + \gamma P_{\pi} v_k) πk+1​=argπmax​(rπ​+γPπ​vk​)

● Value update (VU):

vk+1=rπk+1+γPπk+1vkv_{k+1} = r_{\pi_{k+1}} + \gamma P_{\pi_{k+1}} v_k vk+1​=rπk+1​​+γPπk+1​​vk​

The two algorithms are very similar:

Policy iteration: π0→PEvπ0→PIπ1→PEvπ1→PIπ2→PEvπ2→PI…\pi_0 \xrightarrow{PE} v_{\pi_0} \xrightarrow{PI} \pi_1 \xrightarrow{PE} v_{\pi_1} \xrightarrow{PI} \pi_2 \xrightarrow{PE} v_{\pi_2} \xrightarrow{PI} \ldotsπ0​PE​vπ0​​PI​π1​PE​vπ1​​PI​π2​PE​vπ2​​PI​…

Value iteration: u0→PUπ1′→VUu1→PUπ2′→VUu2→PU…\quad\quad\quad\quad u_0 \xrightarrow{PU} \pi'_1 \xrightarrow{VU} u_1 \xrightarrow{PU} \pi'_2 \xrightarrow{VU} u_2 \xrightarrow{PU} \ldotsu0​PU​π1′​VU​u1​PU​π2′​VU​u2​PU​…

Policy iteration algorithmValue iteration algorithmComments1)Policy:π0N/A2)Value:vπ0=rπ0+γPπ0vπ0v0≐vπ03)Policy:π1=arg⁡max⁡π(rπ+γPπvπ0)π1=arg⁡max⁡π(rπ+γPπv0)Thetwopoliciesarethesame4)Value:vπ1=rπ1+γPπ1vπ1v1=rπ1+γPπ1v0vπ1≥v1sincevπ1≥vπ05)Policy:π2=arg⁡max⁡π(rπ+γPπvπ1)π2′=arg⁡max⁡π(rπ+γPπv1)⋮⋮⋮⋮\begin{array}{c||c|c|c} \hline &\textbf{Policy iteration algorithm} & \textbf{Value iteration algorithm} & \textbf{Comments} \\ \hline 1) Policy: & \pi_0 & N/A & \\ \hline 2) Value: & v_{\pi_0} = r_{\pi_0} + \gamma P_{\pi_0} v_{\pi_0} & v_0 \doteq v_{\pi_0} & \\ \hline 3) Policy: & \pi_1 = \arg \max_{\pi}(r_{\pi} + \gamma P_{\pi} v_{\pi_0}) & \pi_1 = \arg \max_{\pi}(r_{\pi} + \gamma P_{\pi} v_0) & The \quad two \quad policies \quad are \quad the \quad same \\ \hline 4) Value: & \textcolor{skyblue}{v_{\pi_1} = r_{\pi_1} + \gamma P_{\pi_1} v_{\pi_1}} & v_1 = r_{\pi_1} + \gamma P_{\pi_1} v_0 & v_{\pi_1} \geq v_1 \quad since \quad v_{\pi_1} \geq v_{\pi_0} \\ \hline 5) Policy: &\pi_2 = \arg \max_{\pi}(r_{\pi} + \gamma P_{\pi} v_{\pi_1}) & \pi_2' = \arg \max_{\pi}(r_{\pi} + \gamma P_{\pi} v_1) & \\ \hline \vdots & \vdots& \vdots & \vdots \\ \hline \end{array} 1)Policy:2)Value:3)Policy:4)Value:5)Policy:⋮​Policy iteration algorithmπ0​vπ0​​=rπ0​​+γPπ0​​vπ0​​π1​=argmaxπ​(rπ​+γPπ​vπ0​​)vπ1​​=rπ1​​+γPπ1​​vπ1​​π2​=argmaxπ​(rπ​+γPπ​vπ1​​)⋮​Value iteration algorithmN/Av0​≐vπ0​​π1​=argmaxπ​(rπ​+γPπ​v0​)v1​=rπ1​​+γPπ1​​v0​π2′​=argmaxπ​(rπ​+γPπ​v1​)⋮​CommentsThetwopoliciesarethesamevπ1​​≥v1​sincevπ1​​≥vπ0​​⋮​​

  • They start from the same initial condition.
  • The first three steps are the same.
  • The fourth step becomes different:
    • In policy iteration, solving vπ1=rπ1+γPπ1vπ1v_{\pi_1} = r_{\pi_1} + \gamma P_{\pi_1} v_{\pi_1}vπ1​​=rπ1​​+γPπ1​​vπ1​​ requires an iterative algorithm (an infinite number of iterations)
    • In value iteration, v1=rπ1+γPπ1v0v_1 = r_{\pi_1} + \gamma P_{\pi_1} v_0v1​=rπ1​​+γPπ1​​v0​ is a one-step iteration

Consider the step of solving vπ1=rπ1+γPπ1vπ1\textcolor{skyblue}{v_{\pi_1} = r_{\pi_1} + \gamma P_{\pi_1} v_{\pi_1}}vπ1​​=rπ1​​+γPπ1​​vπ1​​:

vπ1(0)=v0value iteration←v1←vπ1(1)=rπ1+γPπ1vπ1(0)vπ1(2)=rπ1+γPπ1vπ1(1)⋮truncated policy iteration←vˉ1←vπ1(j)=rπ1+γPπ1vπ1(j−1)⋮policy iteration←vπ1←vπ1(∞)=rπ1+γPπ1vπ1(∞)\begin{aligned} &\textcolor{hotpink}{v_{\pi_1}^{(0)} = v_0} \\ \text{value iteration} \leftarrow \textcolor{hotpink}{v_1 \leftarrow} &v_{\pi_1}^{(1)} = r_{\pi_1} + \gamma P_{\pi_1} v_{\pi_1}^{(0)} \\ &v_{\pi_1}^{(2)} = r_{\pi_1} + \gamma P_{\pi_1} v_{\pi_1}^{(1)} \\ &\vdots \\ \textcolor{hotpink}{\text{truncated policy iteration}} \leftarrow \textcolor{hotpink}{\bar{v}_1 \leftarrow} &v_{\pi_1}^{(j)} = r_{\pi_1} + \gamma P_{\pi_1} v_{\pi_1}^{(j-1)} \\ &\vdots \\ \text{policy iteration} \leftarrow \textcolor{hotpink}{v_{\pi_1} \leftarrow} &v_{\pi_1}^{(\infty)} = r_{\pi_1} + \gamma P_{\pi_1} v_{\pi_1}^{(\infty)} \end{aligned} value iteration←v1​←truncated policy iteration←vˉ1​←policy iteration←vπ1​​←​vπ1​(0)​=v0​vπ1​(1)​=rπ1​​+γPπ1​​vπ1​(0)​vπ1​(2)​=rπ1​​+γPπ1​​vπ1​(1)​⋮vπ1​(j)​=rπ1​​+γPπ1​​vπ1​(j−1)​⋮vπ1​(∞)​=rπ1​​+γPπ1​​vπ1​(∞)​​

  • The value iteration algorithm computes once.
  • The policy iteration algorithm computes an infinite number of iterations.
  • The truncated policy iteration algorithm computes a finite number of iterations (say jjj). The rest iterations from jjj to ∞\infty∞ are truncated.

Preudocode

Convergence

Proposition (Value Improvement)

Consider the iterative algorithm for solving the policy evaluation step:

vπk(j+1)=rπk+γPπkvπk(j),j=0,1,2,…v_{\pi_k}^{(j+1)} = r_{\pi_k} + \gamma P_{\pi_k} v_{\pi_k}^{(j)}, \quad j = 0, 1, 2, \ldots vπk​(j+1)​=rπk​​+γPπk​​vπk​(j)​,j=0,1,2,…

If the initial guess is selected as vπk(0)=vπk−1v_{\pi_k}^{(0)} = v_{\pi_{k-1}}vπk​(0)​=vπk−1​​, it holds that

vπk(j+1)≥vπk(j)v_{\pi_k}^{(j+1)} \geq v_{\pi_k}^{(j)} vπk​(j+1)​≥vπk​(j)​

for every j=0,1,2,…j = 0, 1, 2, \ldotsj=0,1,2,….

Proof of Proposition

First, since vπk(j)=rπk+γPπkvπk(j−1)v_{\pi_k}^{(j)} = r_{\pi_k} + \gamma P_{\pi_k} v_{\pi_k}^{(j-1)}vπk​(j)​=rπk​​+γPπk​​vπk​(j−1)​ and vπk(j+1)=rπk+γPπkvπk(j)v_{\pi_k}^{(j+1)} = r_{\pi_k} + \gamma P_{\pi_k} v_{\pi_k}^{(j)}vπk​(j+1)​=rπk​​+γPπk​​vπk​(j)​, we have

vπk(j+1)−vπk(j)=γPπk(vπk(j)−vπk(j−1))=⋯=γjPπkj(vπk(1)−vπk(0)).(4.5)v_{\pi_k}^{(j+1)} - v_{\pi_k}^{(j)} = \gamma P_{\pi_k} (v_{\pi_k}^{(j)} - v_{\pi_k}^{(j-1)}) = \cdots = \gamma^j P_{\pi_k}^j (v_{\pi_k}^{(1)} - v_{\pi_k}^{(0)}). \quad (4.5) vπk​(j+1)​−vπk​(j)​=γPπk​​(vπk​(j)​−vπk​(j−1)​)=⋯=γjPπk​j​(vπk​(1)​−vπk​(0)​).(4.5)

Second, since vπk(0)=vπk−1v_{\pi_k}^{(0)} = v_{\pi_{k-1}}vπk​(0)​=vπk−1​​, we have

vπk(1)=rπk+γPπkvπk(0)=rπk+γPπkvπk−1≥rπk−1+γPπk−1vπk−1=vπk−1=vπk(0),v_{\pi_k}^{(1)} = r_{\pi_k} + \gamma P_{\pi_k} v_{\pi_k}^{(0)} = r_{\pi_k} + \gamma P_{\pi_k} v_{\pi_{k-1}} \geq r_{\pi_{k-1}} + \gamma P_{\pi_{k-1}} v_{\pi_{k-1}} = v_{\pi_{k-1}} = v_{\pi_k}^{(0)}, vπk​(1)​=rπk​​+γPπk​​vπk​(0)​=rπk​​+γPπk​​vπk−1​​≥rπk−1​​+γPπk−1​​vπk−1​​=vπk−1​​=vπk​(0)​,

where the inequality is due to πk=arg⁡max⁡π(rπ+γPπvπk−1)\pi_k = \arg \max_{\pi} (r_{\pi} + \gamma P_{\pi} v_{\pi_{k-1}})πk​=argmaxπ​(rπ​+γPπ​vπk−1​​). Substituting vπk(1)≥vπk(0)v_{\pi_k}^{(1)} \geq v_{\pi_k}^{(0)}vπk​(1)​≥vπk​(0)​ into (4.5) yields vπk(j+1)≥vπk(j)v_{\pi_k}^{(j+1)} \geq v_{\pi_k}^{(j)}vπk​(j+1)​≥vπk​(j)​.

The convergence proof of PI is based on that of VI. Since VI converges, we know PI converges.
